Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: By the end of Level 4, students explain how decisions can be made democratically and the role of local government.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: They describe the importance of rules and distinguish between rules and laws.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Students describe how people participate in their community as active citizens, their rights and responsibilities, and factors that shape a person’s identity and communities.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Students identify questions to investigate civics and citizenship issues.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: They describe democratic institutions and systems using information and sources.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: They describe contemporary civics and citizenship issues and use consensus-building and deliberation to negotiate outcomes together.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: By the end of Level 6, students explain the values and features of Australia’s democratic institutions and systems, including the 3 levels of government and electoral systems.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: They explain the roles and responsibilities of key institutions, including how legislation is made and law enforcement.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Students explain the different meanings of citizenship and the roles and responsibilities associated with different kinds of citizenship.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Students develop questions to investigate civics and citizenship issues, using different sources.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Students explain the values and features of democratic institutions and processes through contemporary issues.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: They explain reasons to participate in democratic processes and deliberate on issues that affect their communities.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: They use knowledge and different perspectives from sources to explain contemporary civics and citizenship issues.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: By the end of Level 8, students analyse the roles of key institutions and political actors in Australia’s democracy and the ways in which citizens participate in democracy.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: They explain the characteristics and types of law in Australia, and the principles and features of the Australian legal system, including how citizens can participate in lawmaking.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Students discuss democratic values and their influence on contemporary Australian society, and the diverse perspectives of individuals and groups towards citizenship and identity.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Students describe the nature of Australian society and how Australians express different aspects of their identity and communities, including cultural and religious diversity.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: They discuss the values that support cohesion in Australian society.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Students compare a range of sources and perspectives to refine questions to investigate contemporary political, legal and civic issues.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Students analyse how the values, principles and influences that underpin democratic institutions are expressed, and who exercises power in these institutions.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: They explain reasons for different methods of civic participation and engage in democratic decision-making.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Students develop an analysis of civics and citizenship issues using evidence from diverse perspectives.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: By the end of Level 10, students evaluate the Australian government’s roles and responsibilities at a regional and a global level, including its international legal obligations.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: They analyse the Australian Constitution as the basis of the Australian system of government, the process for constitutional change and the role of parliaments and the High Court of Australia in protecting rights.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Students compare this system of government with at least one other system in the Asia-Pacific region.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: They evaluate the roles of key democratic institutions in public discourse and ways of sustaining a resilient democracy.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Students discuss individual and group participation in global issues and global citizenship.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Using a range of sources and perspectives, students develop and evaluate questions to best investigate contemporary political, legal and civic issues, including global issues.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: They evaluate political, legal and civic institutions nationally and internationally.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: They evaluate the effectiveness of democratic decision-making and methods of civic participation, including by participating in civic processes.

Subject: Civics and Citizenship
Text: Students evaluate civics and citizenship issues using evidence and diverse perspectives.
